# Cambridge IGCSE™  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 170, 183, 187]]<|/det|>
## PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 194, 331, 210]]<|/det|>
Paper 1 Multiple Choice (Core)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 247, 505, 263]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the multiple choice answer sheet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 277, 487, 322]]<|/det|>
You will need: Multiple choice answer sheet Soft clean eraser Soft pencil (type B or HB is recommended)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 337, 227, 352]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 368, 114, 384]]<|/det|>
<label>OR</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>{{}}There are forty questions on this paper. Answer all questions.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 384, 114, 400]]<|/det|>
<label>OR</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[129, 368, 907, 400]]<|/det|>
For each question there are four possible answers \(\mathbf{A}\) , \(\mathbf{B}\) , \(\mathbf{C}\) and \(\mathbf{D}\) . Choose the one you consider correct and record your choice in soft pencil on the multiple choice answer sheet.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 400, 128, 415]]<|/det|>
<label>OR</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[129, 400, 579, 415]]<|/det|>
Follow the instructions on the multiple choice answer sheet.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 415, 123, 431]]<|/det|>
<label>OR</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[129, 415, 277, 431]]<|/det|>
Write in soft pencil.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 431, 868, 462]]<|/det|>
Write your name, centre number and candidate number on the multiple choice answer sheet in the spaces provided unless this has been done for you.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 460, 326, 476]]<|/det|>
Do not use correction fluid.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 476, 366, 492]]<|/det|>
Do not write on any bar codes.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 492, 329, 507]]<|/det|>
You may use a calculator.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 507, 680, 523]]<|/det|>
Take the weight of \(1.0\mathrm{kg}\) to be \(9.8\mathrm{N}\) (acceleration of free fall \(= 9.8\mathrm{m / s}^2\) ).

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 550, 220, 564]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 106, 89]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 672, 89]]<|/det|> The diagram shows rays of light passing through a converging lens. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 101, 616, 119]]<|/det|> Which labelled arrow represents the focal length of the lens? <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[322, 128, 672, 316]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 345, 104, 364]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 345, 920, 380]]<|/det|> The diagram shows a narrow beam of white light being dispersed by a glass prism to produce a visible spectrum. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[316, 388, 678, 500]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 516, 920, 550]]<|/det|> Which statement describes what happens to the frequency and wavelength of the light in observing from P to Q across the spectrum? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 560, 134, 579]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 560, 561, 579]]<|/det|> The frequency and the wavelength both increase. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 586, 134, 604]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 586, 567, 604]]<|/det|> The frequency and the wavelength both decrease. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 612, 134, 631]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 612, 615, 631]]<|/det|> The frequency decreases but the wavelength increases. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 640, 134, 657]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 640, 615, 657]]<|/det|> The frequency increases but the wavelength decreases. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 682, 106, 700]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 682, 920, 715]]<|/det|> The early Universe was filled with gamma radiation. Since then, the radiation has shifted to the microwave region of the electromagnetic spectrum. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 727, 724, 745]]<|/det|> How has this change affected the wavelength and speed of the radiation? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 756, 500, 887]]<|/det|>
wavelengthspeed
Adecreaseddecreased
Bdecreasedstayed the same
Cincreaseddecreased
Dincreasedstayed the same

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[186, 510, 406, 528]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[186, 535, 586, 553]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 565, 536, 583]]<|/det|>

1 and 3 only

<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[645, 593, 761, 611]]<|/det|>
2 and 3 only

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 106, 89]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 902, 89]]<|/det|> A student measures the rate at which ionising radiation is emitted from a radioactive substance. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 102, 700, 120]]<|/det|> He places a detector at different distances from the radioactive source. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[180, 131, 816, 250]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 265, 734, 282]]<|/det|> The table shows how the count rate from the source varies with distance \(d\). <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[186, 294, 813, 345]]<|/det|>
distance d/cm0246
count rate/ counts per minute125011500
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 358, 668, 377]]<|/det|> Which type of ionising radiation is being emitted by the substance? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 388, 139, 406]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 388, 243, 406]]<|/det|> \(\alpha \)-particles <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 415, 134, 433]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 415, 242, 433]]<|/det|> \(\beta \)-particles <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 444, 134, 462]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 444, 203, 462]]<|/det|> \(\gamma \)-rays <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 470, 133, 488]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 470, 210, 488]]<|/det|> X-rays <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 514, 106, 532]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 514, 801, 532]]<|/det|> Radioactive decay results in the emission of \(\alpha\)-particles, \(\beta\)-particles and \(\gamma\)-radiation. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 543, 801, 561]]<|/det|> Which types of emission result in a nucleus changing to that of a different element? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 573, 131, 591]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 573, 507, 591]]<|/det|> \(\alpha\)-particle emission and \(\beta\)-particle emission <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 600, 131, 618]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 600, 517, 618]]<|/det|> \(\alpha\)-particle emission and \(\gamma\)-radiation emission <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 628, 131, 646]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 628, 517, 646]]<|/det|> \(\beta\)-particle emission and \(\gamma\)-radiation emission <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 655, 133, 673]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 655, 359, 673]]<|/det|> \(\gamma\)-radiation emission only <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 698, 107, 715]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 698, 539, 715]]<|/det|> A radioactive isotope has a half-life of 120 minutes. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 728, 561, 746]]<|/det|> It emits radiation at a rate of 100 particles per second. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 758, 769, 776]]<|/det|> How long does it take for the rate of emission to fall to 25 particles per second? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 787, 133, 804]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 787, 245, 804]]<|/det|> 30 minutes <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[280, 787, 306, 804]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[320, 787, 415, 804]]<|/det|> 45 minutes <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[448, 787, 475, 804]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[480, 787, 581, 804]]<|/det|> 90 minutes <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[615, 787, 636, 804]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[650, 787, 710, 804]]<|/det|> 240 minutes

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 404, 107, 422]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 404, 504, 422]]<|/det|> Which statement about the Sun is not correct? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 433, 134, 452]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 433, 445, 452]]<|/det|> The Sun is one of the biggest stars. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 459, 133, 477]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 459, 440, 477]]<|/det|> The Sun emits ultraviolet radiation. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 484, 133, 503]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 484, 423, 503]]<|/det|> The Sun emits infrared radiation. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 510, 133, 529]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 510, 388, 529]]<|/det|> Helium is present in the Sun. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 555, 107, 574]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 555, 579, 574]]<|/det|> Which statement about the Milky Way galaxy is correct? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 584, 131, 602]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 584, 781, 602]]<|/det|> It contains stars that are about the same distance from the Earth as the Sun. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 610, 131, 628]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 610, 715, 628]]<|/det|> It is a collection of about 1000 stars that can be seen from the Earth. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 636, 133, 655]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 636, 574, 655]]<|/det|> It is the galaxy that contains the Sun and the Earth. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 662, 133, 680]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 662, 425, 680]]<|/det|> Its diameter is about 1 light-year. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 839, 920, 873]]<|/det|> Permission to reproduce items where third-party owned material protected by copyright is included has been sought and cleared where possible.
